summary.long: 2 Samuel is a book of the Old Testament.

verses.text: Now after the death of Saul, David returned from killing the Amalekites and stayed two days in Ziklag.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the third day, a man came from the tents of Saul. His clothes were torn and he had dust on his head. When he came to David, he fell with his face to the ground.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David said to him, “Where do you come from?” And he answered, “I have run away from the tents of Israel.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David said to him, “How did it go? Tell me.” And the man said, “The people have run from the battle. Many have fallen and are dead. Saul and his son Jonathan are dead also.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David said to the young man, “How do you know that Saul and his son Jonathan are dead?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The young man said, “I happened to be on Mount Gilboa. There I saw Saul holding himself up with his spear. The war-wagons and the horsemen were coming close after him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he looked behind him, he saw me. He called to me and I said, ‘Here I am.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said to me, ‘Who are you?’ And I answered, ‘I am an Amalekite.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he said to me, ‘I beg you, stand beside me and kill me. I am in pain, and yet I am still alive.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So I stood beside him and killed him, because I knew he could not live after he had fallen. Then I took the crown which was on his head and the beautiful gold band which he wore on his arm, and I have brought them here to my lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David took hold of his clothes and tore them, and so did all the men who were with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They cried in sorrow and did not eat until evening, because of Saul and his son Jonathan, and of the people of the Lord and of the family of Israel. For they had fallen by the sword.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David said to the young man, “Where are you from?” And he answered, “I am the son of one from another land, an Amalekite.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David said to him, “Why were you not afraid to put out your hand to destroy the Lord’s chosen one?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David called one of the young men and said, “Go, cut him down.” So he hit him and he died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David said to him, “Your blood is on your head. Because your mouth has spoken against you, saying, ‘I have killed the Lord’s chosen one.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David sang a song of sorrow for Saul and his son Jonathan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He told them to teach the song of the bow to the people of Judah. See, it is written in the book of Jashar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “O Israel, your beauty is destroyed on your high places! How have the powerful fallen!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Do not tell about it in Gath. Do not tell about it in the streets of Ashkelon, or the daughters of the Philistines might be filled with joy. The daughters of those who have not gone through our religious act might be filled with joy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: O mountains of Gilboa, do not let the water that is on the grass in the early morning or rain be on you. Let not grass be grown on your fields. For there the covering of the powerful was made dirty, the covering of Saul, as if he had not been set apart with oil.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The bow of Jonathan did not turn away. The sword of Saul did not return empty. They did not turn from the blood of the dead and the fat of the powerful.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul and Jonathan were loved and pleasing in their life. And they were not divided in their death. They were faster than eagles. They were stronger than lions.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: O daughters of Israel, cry for Saul. He dressed you in fine red clothing. He put on your clothing objects of gold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: How have the powerful fallen in the center of the battle! Jonathan has been killed on your high places.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I am troubled because of you, my brother Jonathan. You have been very pleasing to me. Your love to me was greater than the love of women.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: How have the powerful fallen, and the bows and swords of war destroyed!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After this, David asked the Lord, “Should I go up to one of the cities of Judah?” And the Lord said to him, “Go up.” So David said, “Where should I go?” And He said, “To Hebron.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David went up there with his two wives, Ahinoam of Jezreel, and Abigail who had been the wife of Nabal of Carmel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David brought up his men who were with him, each one with those of his family. They lived in the cities of Hebron.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then the men of Judah came and there they chose David to be king over the family of Judah.
They told David, “It was the men of Jabesh-gilead who buried Saul.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David sent men with news to the men of Jabesh-gilead, saying, “May the Lord bring good to you. Because you have shown kindness to your king Saul, and have buried him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now may the Lord show loving-kindness and truth to you. And I will do good to you, because you have done this.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So now let your hands be strong. Have strength of heart. For your king Saul is dead. And those of the family of Judah have chosen me to be their king.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Abner the son of Ner, captain of Saul’s army, had taken Saul’s son Ish-bosheth to Mahanaim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He made him king of Gilead, the Ashurites, Jezreel, Ephraim, Benjamin, and all Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul’s son Ish-bosheth was forty years old when he became king of Israel. He was king for two years. But the family of Judah followed David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David was king in Hebron over the family of Judah for seven years and six months.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Abner the son of Ner went out from Mahanaim to Gibeon with the servants of Saul’s son Ish-bosheth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Zeruiah’s son Joab and the servants of David went out and met them by the pool of Gibeon. One group sat down on one side of the pool, and the other group on the other side.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Abner said to Joab, “Let the young men get up and have a test of strength in front of us.” And Joab said, “Let them get up.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they stood up and went over by number. There were twelve for Benjamin and Ish-bosheth the son of Saul, and twelve of the servants of David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Each one of them took hold of the head of the one fighting against him, and put his sword into the other’s side. So they fell down together. That is why that place was called field of swords, which is in Gibeon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The battle was very bad that day. Abner and the men of Israel were beaten by the servants of David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now the three sons of Zeruiah were there, Joab and Abishai and Asahel. Asahel was as fast as a wild deer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Asahel ran after Abner. He did not turn to the right or the left from following him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Abner looked behind him and said, “Is that you, Asahel?” And he answered, “It is I.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Abner said to him, “Turn aside to your right or left. Take hold of one of the young men, and take for yourself what belongs to him.” But Asahel was not willing to turn aside from following him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abner said again to Asahel, “Turn aside from following me. Why should I make you fall? How then could I lift up my face to your brother Joab?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But he would not turn aside. So Abner hit him in the stomach with the end of his spear, so that the spear came out at his back. He fell there and died where he fell. And all who came to the place where Asahel fell and died, stood still.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Joab and Abishai went after Abner. When the sun was going down, they came to the hill of Ammah, which is before Giah by the way of the desert of Gibeon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sons of Benjamin gathered together behind Abner and became one army. They stood on the top of a hill.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abner called to Joab and said, “Should the sword destroy forever? Do you not know that it will be bad in the end? How long will you keep from telling the people to stop following their brothers?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab said, “As God lives, if you had not spoken, for sure the people would have stopped going after their brothers in the morning.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Joab sounded the horn, and all the people stopped and went after Israel no longer. And they did not fight any more.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abner and his men went all night through the Arabah. They crossed the Jordan, walked all morning, and came to Mahanaim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab returned from following Abner, and gathered all the people together. Added to Asahel, nineteen of David’s servants were missing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the servants of David had killed many of Benjamin and Abner’s men, so that 360 men died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They picked up Asahel and buried him in his father’s grave in Bethlehem. Then Joab and his men walked all night and came to Hebron early the next morning.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was a long war between the family of Saul and the family of David. David became stronger and stronger. But the family of Saul became weaker and weaker.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Sons were born to David at Hebron. His first-born was Amnon, by David’s wife Ahinoam of Jezreel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His second son was Chileab, by Abigail who had been the wife of Nabal of Carmel. The third was Absalom the son of Maacah, the daughter of Talmai, king of Geshur.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The fourth was Adonijah the son of Haggith. The fifth was Shephatiah the son of Abital.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the sixth was Ithream, by David’s wife Eglah. These sons were born to David at Hebron.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While there was war between the family of Saul and the family of David, Abner was making himself strong in the family of Saul.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Saul had a woman acting as his wife whose name was Rizpah, the daughter of Aiah. Ish-bosheth said to Abner, “Why have you gone in to the woman who acted as my father’s wife?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abner was very angry because of Ish-bosheth’s words, and said, “Am I a dog’s head that belongs to Judah? Today I show kindness to the family of your father Saul, to his brothers and to his friends. I have not given you into David’s hands. Yet today you say I am guilty because of this woman.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: May God do so to Abner, and more also, if I do not do for David what the Lord has promised him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He has promised to build the throne of David over Israel and over Judah, from Dan to Beersheba.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Ish-bosheth could not answer Abner, because he was afraid of him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Abner sent men with news to David at Hebron, saying, “Whose land is this? Make your agreement with me, and I will help you bring all Israel over to you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David said, “Good! I will make an agreement with you. But you must do one thing that I say. You will not see my face unless you first bring Saul’s daughter Michal when you come to see me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David sent men to Saul’s son Ish-bosheth, saying, “Give me my wife Michal. I was married to her by giving a hundred pieces of skin from the sex parts of the Philistines.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Ish-bosheth sent men to take her from her husband Paltiel the son of Laish.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But her husband went with her, crying as he went. He followed her as far as Bahurim. Then Abner said to him, “Go, return.” So he returned.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Abner spoke with the leaders of Israel, saying, “In times past you wanted David to be your king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now make it happen! For the Lord has said of David, ‘By the hand of My servant David I will save My people Israel from the Philistines and from all those who hate them.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abner spoke to Benjamin also. Then Abner went to Hebron to tell David all that Israel and the whole family of Benjamin thought was good to do.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abner came with twenty men to David at Hebron. And David made a special supper for Abner and the men who were with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abner said to David, “Let me go and gather all Israel to my lord the king so they may make an agreement with you. Then you may be king over all your heart desires.” So David sent Abner away, and he went in peace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David’s servants and Joab came from a battle and brought with them many good things they had taken. But Abner was not with David in Hebron, for David had sent him away. Abner had gone in peace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Joab and the army with him came, it was told to Joab, “Abner the son of Ner came to the king. And the king has sent him away in peace.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joab came to the king and said, “What have you done? See, Abner came to you. Why then have you sent him away, so that he is gone?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You know Abner the son of Ner. He came to fool you, and to learn about your going out and coming in. He came to learn all that you are doing.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Joab left David, he sent men after Abner. They brought him back from the well of Sirah. But David did not know it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Abner returned to Hebron, Joab took him aside into the center of the gate to speak with him alone. There Joab hit him in the stomach and killed him because of the blood of his brother Asahel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David heard about it, he said, “I and my nation are forever without guilt before the Lord, from the blood of Abner the son of Ner.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: May the guilt be on the head of Joab and all his father’s family. May the family of Joab never be without one who has a flow from his body, or a bad skin disease, or the need to use a walking stick. Or may his family never be without one who falls by the sword, or who needs more bread.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Joab and his brother Abishai killed Abner because he had killed their brother in the battle at Gibeon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David said to Joab and all the people who were with him, “Tear your clothes and dress in clothes made from hair. Cry in sorrow in front of Abner.” And King David walked behind the box in which the dead man was carried.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They buried Abner in Hebron. And the king cried in a loud voice at Abner’s grave. All the people cried.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king sang a song of sorrow for Abner, saying, “Should Abner die as a fool dies?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Your hands were not tied. Your feet were not put in chains. You have fallen as one falls in front of the sinful.” And all the people cried again over him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then all the people came to try to talk David into eating bread while it was still day. But David promised, saying, “May God do so to me, and more also, if I taste bread or anything else before the sun goes down.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the people saw it, and it pleased them. Everything the king did pleased all the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So all the people and all Israel understood that day that it had not been the king’s will to kill Abner the son of Ner.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king said to his servants, “Do you not know that a leader, and a great man has fallen this day in Israel?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And I am weak today, even if I was chosen to be king. The sons of Zeruiah are too hard for me. May the Lord pay the sinner for his sin.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Saul’s son Ish-bosheth heard that Abner had died in Hebron, he lost his strength of heart. All Israel was troubled.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul’s son had two men who were captains of small armies. The name of one was Baanah, and the name of the other was Rechab. They were sons of Rimmon the Beerothite of Benjamin. (For Beeroth is thought of as part of Benjamin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people of Beeroth ran to Gittaim, and have been strangers there to this day.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Saul’s son Jonathan had a son who could not walk because of his feet. He was five years old when the news of Saul and Jonathan came from Jezreel. His nurse had picked him up and ran. In her hurry to get away, he fell and hurt his feet so he could not walk. His name was Mephibosheth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sons of Rimmon the Beerothite, Rechab and Baanah, left and came to the family of Ish-bosheth. It was during the heat of the day, while Ish-bosheth was taking his noon rest.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They came to the center of the house as if to get wheat, and they hit Ish-bosheth in the stomach. Then Rechab and his brother Baanah ran away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They had come into the house while he was lying on his bed in his room. And they had hit him and killed him and cut off his head. They took his head and traveled by the way of Arabah all night.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they brought Ish-bosheth’s head to David at Hebron, and said to the king, “See, the head of Ish-bosheth, the son of Saul, who hated you and tried to kill you. So this day the Lord has punished Saul and his children for the king.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David answered Rechab and Baanah his brother, sons of Rimmon the Beerothite. He said to them, “As the Lord lives, Who has saved my life from all trouble,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: when one told me, ‘See, Saul is dead,’ he thought he was bringing good news. But I took hold of him and killed him in Ziklag. This was the reward I gave him for his news.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: How much worse it is when sinful men have killed a man who is right and good, on his bed in his own house! Should I not now punish you for his blood and destroy you from the earth?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David had the young men kill them and cut off their hands and feet. They hung them up beside the pool in Hebron. But they took the head of Ish-bosheth and buried it in Abner’s grave in Hebron.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then all the families of Israel came to David at Hebron and said, “See, we are your bone and your flesh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Saul was our king, you were the one who led Israel out and in. The Lord said to you, ‘You will be the shepherd of My people Israel. You will be a ruler over Israel.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So all the leaders of Israel came to the king at Hebron. And there King David made an agreement with them before the Lord. Then they chose David to be the king of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David was thirty years old when he became king, and he ruled for forty years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He ruled over Judah seven years and six months at Hebron. Then he ruled in Jerusalem thirty-three years over all Israel and Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now the king and his men went to Jerusalem against the Jebusites, the people living in the land. They said to David, “You will not come here. Even those who cannot see or walk could stop you.” They thought that David could not come here.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But David took the strong place of Zion, that is, the city of David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David said on that day, “Whoever would kill the Jebusites, let him go up through the hole where the water flows, to those who cannot walk or see and who are hated by David’s soul.” So it is said, “Those who cannot see or walk will not come to the house.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David lived in the strong place and called it the city of David. He built all around it from Millo toward the center.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David became greater and greater, for the Lord God of All was with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hiram king of Tyre sent men to David with cedar trees and men who build with wood and stone. And they built a house for David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David understood that the Lord had made him the king of Israel, and that the Lord had given honor to David’s rule because of His people Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David took more wives from Jerusalem, after he came from Hebron. And more sons and daughters were born to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The names of those who were born to him in Jerusalem were Shammua, Shobab, Nathan, Solomon,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ibhar, Elishua, Nepheg, Japhia,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Elishama, Eliada and Eliphelet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the Philistines heard that David had been chosen to be king of Israel, all the Philistines went up to find him. When David heard of it, he went down to the strong place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Philistines came and spread themselves out in the valley of Rephaim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David asked the Lord, “Should I go up against the Philistines? Will You give them into my hand?” And the Lord said to David, “Go up, for it is sure that I will give the Philistines into your hand.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David came to Baal-perazim and beat them there in battle. He said, “The Lord has broken through those who hate me like the breaking through of a flood.” So he gave that place the name Baal-perazim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Philistines left their false gods there, and David and his men carried them away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Philistines came up again, and spread themselves out in the valley of Rephaim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David asked the Lord what he should do. And the Lord said, “Do not go up, but go around behind them and come at them in front of the balsam trees.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When you hear the sound of their steps in the tops of the balsam trees, then hurry to fight, for then the Lord will have gone out before you to destroy the Philistine army.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David did just as the Lord told him. He killed the Philistines from Geba to Gezer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Again David gathered all the chosen men of Israel. There were 30,000.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He got up and went with all the people who were with him to Baale-judah to bring from there the special box of God. It is called by the name of the Lord of All Who sits on His throne above the cherubim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They carried the special box of God on a new wagon, and brought it out of the family of Abinadab which was on the hill. Abinadab’s sons Uzzah and Ahio were leading the new wagon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They brought it with the special box of God from the family of Abinadab, which was on the hill. Ahio was walking in front of the special box.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And David and all those of the family of Israel sang and danced before the Lord with all their strength. They played songs with harps and timbrels.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the cattle pulling the wagon almost made the special box of God fall when they came to the grain-floor of Nacon. So Uzzah put out his hand and took hold of the special box so it would not fall.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The anger of the Lord burned against Uzzah. God killed him there for his mistake. And he died there by the special box of God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David became angry because the Lord had gone against Uzzah. So that place is called Perez-uzzah to this day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David was afraid of the Lord that day, and he said, “How can the special box of the Lord come to me?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David was not willing to move the special box of the Lord into the city of David. But he took it aside to the house of Obed-edom the Gittite.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The special box of the Lord stayed in the house of Obed-edom the Gittite for three months. And the Lord brought good to Obed-edom and all of his family.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now it was told to King David, “The Lord has brought good to the house of Obed-edom and all that belongs to him, because of the special box of God.” So David went and brought the special box of God from Obed-edom’s family into the city of David with joy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the men who carried the special box of the Lord had gone six steps, David killed and gave to the Lord a bull and a fat calf.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He was dancing before the Lord with all his strength. And he was wearing a linen vest.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David and all those of the family of Israel were bringing the special box of the Lord with a loud voice and the sound of the horn.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As the special box of the Lord came into the city of David, Saul’s daughter Michal looked out of the window. She saw King David jumping and dancing before the Lord, and she hated him in her heart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They brought in the special box of the Lord and put it in its place inside the tent David had set up for it. And David gave burnt gifts and peace gifts to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he had finished giving the burnt gifts and peace gifts, David prayed that good would come to the people in the name of the Lord of All.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he gave a loaf of bread, a loaf of dates and a loaf of dried grapes to each man and woman of all the people of Israel. And all the people went home.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David returned to pray that good would come to his family. But Saul’s daughter Michal came out to meet him, and said, “How the king of Israel honored himself today! He took his clothes off today so that his servants’ young women would see him. He acted like one of the foolish ones taking his clothes off without shame!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David said to Michal, “It was before the Lord. He chose me over your father and all his family, and made me ruler over the people of the Lord, over Israel. So I will act with joy before the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will be honored less than this. I will be without pride in my own eyes. But the young women you have spoken about will honor me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Saul’s daughter Michal had no child to the day of her death.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King David lived in his house. The Lord had given him rest from all those around him who hated him. At this time,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the king said to Nathan, the man who spoke for God, “See now, I live in a house of cedar wood. But the special box of God stays within tent curtains.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nathan said to the king, “Go and do all that is in your mind. For the Lord is with you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But that same night the word of the Lord came to Nathan, saying,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Go and tell My servant David, ‘This is what the Lord says, “Are you the one who should build a house for Me to live in?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I have not lived in a house since the day I brought the people of Israel from Egypt to this day. But I have been moving about with a tent to live in.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In all the places where I have moved with all the people of Israel, did I say anything about this to any of the families of Israel which I told to shepherd My people? Did I say to any of them, ‘Why have you not built a house of cedar wood for Me?’”’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So now tell My servant David, ‘This is what the Lord of All says, “I took you from following the sheep in the field to be the ruler of My people Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I have been with you in all the places you have gone. I have destroyed from in front of you all those who fought against you. I will make you a great name, like the names of the great men who are on the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will choose a place for My people Israel and will plant them, that they may live in their own place and not be troubled again. The sinful will not bring trouble to them any more, as they did before
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: since the day I told special people to rule My people Israel. I will give you rest from all those who hate you. And the Lord makes known to you that He will make a house for you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When your days are done and you lie down with your fathers, I will raise up your son after you, who will be born from you. And I will build his nation.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He will build a house for My name, and I will build the throne of his nation to last forever.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will be a Father to him and he will be a son to Me. When he sins, I will punish him with the stick of men. And I will let the sons of men hit him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But My loving-kindness will not leave him, as I took it away from Saul, whom I took away from you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Your house and your nation will be made sure before Me forever. Your throne will be built to last forever.”’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nathan said to David all these words of this special dream.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then King David went in and sat before the Lord, and said, “Who am I, O Lord God, and what is my family, that You have brought me this far?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yet this was a small thing in Your eyes, O Lord God. You have spoken of Your servant’s family in the future. And this is the way of man, O Lord God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: What more can David say to You? For You know Your servant, O Lord God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Because of Your Word and Your own heart, You have done all these great things to let Your servant know.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For this reason You are great, O Lord God. There is none like You. And there is no God but You, by all that we have heard with our ears.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: What other nation on earth is like Your people Israel. God went to make them free to be His people and to make a name for Himself. You did a great thing for Yourself and great things for Your land. You did them before Your people whom You have made free from Egypt, from nations and their gods.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For You have made for Yourself Your people Israel to be Your people forever. O Lord, You have become their God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now, O Lord God, make sure forever the word which You have spoken about Your servant and his family. Do as You have said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Your name will be honored forever. It will be said, ‘The Lord of All is God over Israel.’ May the family of Your servant David be made strong before You.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For You, O Lord of All, the God of Israel, have shown this to Your servant, saying, ‘I will build a house for you.’ So Your servant has found strength of heart to pray this prayer to You.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And now, O Lord God, You are God. Your Words are truth. And You have promised this good thing to Your servant.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So now may it please You to bring good to the house of Your servant, that it may last forever before You. For You have spoken, O Lord God. May Your good come to the family of Your servant forever.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After this David won the battle against the Philistines. And he took the most important city from the Philistines.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He won the battle against Moab, and had them lie down on the ground in straight groups. Two groups were put to death, and one group was kept alive. The Moabites became servants to David and paid taxes to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David won the battle against Hadadezer the son of Rehob king of Zobah, as he went to get his power again at the Euphrates River.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David took 1,700 horsemen and 20,000 foot soldiers from him. He cut the legs of some of the war-wagon horses, but saved enough of them for 100 war-wagons.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the Syrians of Damascus came to help Hadadezer king of Zobah, David killed 22,000 of them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he put groups of soldiers in Damascus of Syria. The Syrians became servants to David and were made to pay taxes to him. The Lord helped David every place he went.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David took the coverings of gold which were carried by Hadadezer’s army, and brought them to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And he took a very large amount of brass from Hadadezer’s cities, Betah and Berothai.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Toi king of Hamath heard that David had won the battle against the whole army of Hadadezer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Toi sent his son Joram to King David, to greet him and pray that good would come to him, because David had fought against Hadadezer and had won. Hadadezer had been at war with Toi. Joram brought with him objects of silver, gold and brass.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David set these apart to the Lord, together with the silver and gold he had set apart from all the nations he had taken in battle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He had taken silver and gold from Syria, Moab, the sons of Ammon, the Philistines, Amalek, and from the things taken from Hadadezer the son of Rehob, king of Zobah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David’s name was very respected when he returned from killing 18,000 Syrians in the Valley of Salt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And he put groups of soldiers in Edom. In all Edom he put soldiers, and all the Edomites became servants to David. The Lord helped David every place he went.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David ruled all of Israel. He did what was right and good and fair for all his people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab the son of Zeruiah was the head of the army. Jehoshaphat the son of Ahilud wrote down the important things of the nation.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahitub’s son Zadok and Abiathar’s son Ahimelech were religious leaders. Seraiah was the writer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Benaiah the son of Jehoiada ruled the Cherethites and the Pelethites. And David’s sons were the king’s helpers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David said, “Is there anyone left of the family of Saul, to whom I may show kindness because of Jonathan?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now there was a servant in Saul’s house whose name was Ziba. They called him to David, and the king said to him, “Are you Ziba?” And he said, “I am your servant.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king said, “Is there not still someone of the family of Saul to whom I may show the kindness of God?” And Ziba said to the king, “There is still a son of Jonathan who cannot walk because of his feet.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the king said to him, “Where is he?” Ziba answered the king, “See, he is in the family of Machir the son of Ammiel in Lo-debar.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then King David sent men to bring him from the family of Machir the son of Ammiel, from Lo-debar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Mephibosheth the son of Saul’s son Jonathan came to David and fell on his face to the ground in respect. David said, “Mephibosheth.” And he answered, “Here is your servant!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David said to him, “Do not be afraid. For I will be sure to show kindness to you because of your father Jonathan. I will return to you all the land of your grandfather Saul. And you will eat at my table always.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Again Mephibosheth put his face to the ground and said, “Who am I? Why should you care for a dead dog like me?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king called Saul’s servant Ziba and said to him, “I have given to your owner’s grandson all that belonged to Saul and his family.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You and your sons and your servants will grow food on the land for him. You will bring in the food so your owner’s grandson may eat. But Mephibosheth your owner’s grandson will always eat at my table.” Now Ziba had fifteen sons and twenty servants.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Ziba said to the king, “Your servant will do all that my lord the king tells your servant to do.” So Mephibosheth ate at David’s table as one of the king’s sons.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Mephibosheth had a young son whose name was Mica. And all who lived in Ziba’s house were Mephibosheth’s servants.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Mephibosheth lived in Jerusalem, for he always ate at the king’s table. Both his feet had been hurt and he could not walk.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After this the king of the Ammonites died. His son Hanun became king in his place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David said, “I will show kindness to Nahash’s son Hanun, just as his father showed kindness to me.” So David sent some of his servants to comfort him in the loss of his father. But when David’s servants came to the land of the Ammonites,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the Ammonite leaders said to their lord Hanun, “Do you think that David is honoring your father because he sent men to comfort you? Has he not sent his servants to you so they can spy out the city and destroy it?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Hanun took David’s servants and cut off half the hair from their faces. Then he cut off half their clothing, almost up to the belt, and sent them away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David heard about it, he sent men to meet them, for they were very ashamed. The king said, “Stay at Jericho until the hair grows again on your faces. Then return.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now when the sons of Ammon saw that they had become hated by David, they paid for the help of the Syrians of Beth-rehob and the Syrians of Zobah, 20,000 foot soldiers. And they paid for the help of the king of Maacah with 1,000 men, and 12,000 men of Tob.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David heard about it, he sent Joab and all the army of the powerful men.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sons of Ammon came to the city gate and got ready for battle. And the Syrians of Zobah and of Rehob, and the men of Tob and Maacah, were by themselves in the field.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab saw that the battle was set against him both in front and behind him. So he chose all the best men of Israel and dressed them for battle against the Syrians.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He put the rest of the people under the rule of his brother Abishai. He dressed them for battle against the sons of Ammon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab said, “If the Syrians are too strong for me, then help me. But if the sons of Ammon are too strong for you, then I will come and help you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Be strong. Let us show ourselves to have strength of heart because of our people and the cities of our God. And may the Lord do what is good in His eyes.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Joab and the people who were with him came near to battle against the Syrians, and they ran away from him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the sons of Ammon saw that the Syrians had run away, they ran away from Abishai and went into the city. Then Joab returned from fighting against the sons of Ammon, and came to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the Syrians saw that they had lost the battle against Israel, they gathered together.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hadadezer sent men and brought out the Syrians who were on the other side of the Euphrates River, and they came to Helam. They were led by Shobach, the captain of Hadadezer’s army.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When it was told to David, he gathered all Israel together and crossed the Jordan, and came to Helam. The Syrians dressed themselves for battle against David, and fought against him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the Syrians ran away from Israel. David killed 700 drivers of the Syrian war-wagons, and 40,000 horsemen. He killed Shobach, the captain of their army, who died there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When all the kings who were servants of Hadadezer saw that they had lost the battle against Israel, they made peace with Israel and served them. The Syrians were afraid to help the sons of Ammon any more.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The spring of the year was the time when kings went out to battle. At that time David sent Joab and his servants and all Israel. They destroyed the sons of Ammon and gathered the army around Rabbah. But David stayed at Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When evening came David got up from his bed and walked around on the roof of the king’s house. From the roof he saw a woman washing herself. The woman was very beautiful.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David sent someone to ask about the woman. And one said, “Is this not Eliam’s daughter Bathsheba, the wife of Uriah the Hittite?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David sent men and took her. When she came to him, he lay with her. After she had made herself clean again, she returned to her house.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She was going to have a baby, so she sent someone to tell David, “I am going to have a baby.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David sent men to Joab, saying, “Send me Uriah the Hittite.” So Joab sent Uriah to David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Uriah came to him, David asked how Joab and the people were doing, and how the war was going.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David said to Uriah, “Go down to your house, and wash your feet.” And Uriah left the king’s house, and a gift from the king was sent to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Uriah slept at the door of the king’s house with all the servants of his lord. He did not go down to his house.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they told David that Uriah did not go down to his house, David said to Uriah, “Have you not returned from traveling a long way? Why did you not go down to your house?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Uriah said to David, “The special box of the Lord, and Israel and Judah, are staying in tents. My lord Joab and the servants of my lord are staying in the open field. Should I go to my house to eat and drink and lie with my wife? By your life and the life of your soul, I will not do this thing.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David said to Uriah, “Stay here today also. Tomorrow I will let you go.” So Uriah stayed in Jerusalem that day and the next.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David called him, and he ate and drank with him, and David made him drunk. In the evening Uriah went out to lie on his bed with his lord’s servants. He did not go down to his house.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the morning, David wrote a letter to Joab, and sent it by Uriah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He had written in the letter, “Put Uriah in the front of the hardest battle and come away from him, so that he may be killed.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So while Joab was watching the city, he sent Uriah to the place where he knew there were soldiers with strength of heart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The men of the city went out and fought against Joab. Some of David’s servants were killed. And Uriah the Hittite died also.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joab sent a man with news to David to tell him all about the war.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab told the man, “When you have finished telling the king all about the war,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the king might become angry. He might say to you, ‘Why did you go so near the city to fight? Did you not know that they would shoot from the wall?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Who killed Abimelech the son of Jerubbesheth? Did not a woman throw a grinding stone on him from the wall so that he died at Thebez? Why did you go so near the wall?’ Then you should say, ‘Your servant Uriah the Hittite is dead also.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the man left and came to David. He told him all that Joab had sent him to tell.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The man said to David, “The men were winning the fight against us. They came out against us in the field. But we drove them back as far as the city gate.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they shot arrows at your servants from the wall. So some of the king’s servants are dead, and your servant Uriah the Hittite is dead also.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David said to the man, “Tell Joab, ‘Do not let this thing trouble you. For the sword kills one as well as another. Make your battle against the city stronger and destroy it.’ Comfort him with these words.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Uriah’s wife heard that her husband was dead, she was filled with sorrow for him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the time of sorrow was finished, David sent men and brought her to his house. She became his wife, and gave birth to his son. But what David had done was sinful in the eyes of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord sent Nathan to David. He came to him and said, “There were two men in one city. One was rich and the other was poor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The rich man had many flocks and cattle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the poor man had nothing except one little female lamb which he bought and fed. It grew up together with him and his children. It would eat his bread and drink from his cup and lie in his arms. It was like a daughter to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now a traveler came to the rich man. But the rich man was not willing to take from his own flock or his own cattle, to make food for the traveler who had come to him. Instead, he took the poor man’s female lamb and made it ready for the man who had come to him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David was very angry at the man, and said to Nathan, “As the Lord lives, for sure the man who has done this should die.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And he must pay four times the worth of the lamb, because he did this thing without pity.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nathan said to David, “You are the man! This is what the Lord God of Israel says: ‘I chose you to be the king of Israel. I saved you from the hand of Saul.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I gave you Saul’s family and Saul’s wives into your care. I gave you the nations of Israel and Judah. And if this were too little, I would give you as much more.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Why have you hated the Word of the Lord by doing what is bad in His eyes? You have killed Uriah the Hittite with the sword. You have taken his wife to be your wife. You have killed him with the sword of the sons of Ammon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So now some from your family, even in the future, will die by the sword, because you have turned against Me and have taken the wife of Uriah the Hittite to be your wife.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what the Lord says: ‘See, I will bring trouble against you from your own family. I will take your wives in front of your eyes and give them to your neighbor. He will lie with your wives in the light of day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You did it in secret. But I will do this in front of all Israel, and under the sun.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David said to Nathan, “I have sinned against the Lord.” And Nathan said to him, “The Lord has taken away your sin. You will not die.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But by this act you have given those who hate the Lord a reason to speak against the Lord. The child that is born to you will die for sure.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then Nathan went home.
The Lord sent trouble upon the child of Uriah’s wife and David, so that he was very sick.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David begged God to make the child well. He went without food and lay all night on the ground.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The leaders of his family stood beside him to lift him up from the ground. But David was not willing. He would not eat food with them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The child died on the seventh day. And David’s servants were afraid to tell him that the child was dead, for they said, “See, we spoke to him while the child was still alive, and he did not listen to us. So how can we tell him the child is dead? He might hurt himself.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when David saw his servants speaking together in secret, he understood that the child was dead. He asked his servants, “Is the child dead?” And they said, “He is dead.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David got up from the ground, washed, poured oil on himself, and changed his clothes. Then he came into the house of the Lord and worshiped. He returned to his own house and asked for food. So they set food in front of him, and he ate.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then his servants said to him, “What is this that you have done? While the child was alive, you went without food and cried. But when the child died, you got up and ate food.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David said, “I went without food and cried while the child was still alive, for I said, ‘Who knows? The Lord might be kind to me and let the child live.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But now he has died. Why should I go without food? Can I bring him to life again? I will go to him, but he will not return to me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David comforted his wife Bathsheba. He went in and lay with her, and she gave birth to a son. He gave him the name Solomon. The Lord loved him,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and sent word through Nathan who spoke for God. And Nathan gave him the name Jedidiah because of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Joab fought against Rabbah of the sons of Ammon, and took the king’s city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab sent men to David, saying, “I have fought against Rabbah. I have taken the city of waters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So gather the rest of the people together. Go against the city and take it, or I will take the city myself and it will be called by my name.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David gathered all the people and went to Rabbah. He fought against it, and took it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he took the very heavy crown from their king’s head. In it were beautiful stones of much worth. The crown was put on David’s head. And he brought a large amount of things out of the city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He brought out the people who were in it also. He made them work with saws, sharp iron tools, and iron axes. And he made them work in the heat making building stones. He did this to all the cities of the sons of Ammon. Then David and all the people returned to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now David’s son Absalom had a beautiful sister whose name was Tamar. And David’s son Amnon loved her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Amnon was so troubled because of his sister Tamar that he became sick. She was a woman who had never had a man, and Amnon thought how hard it would be to have her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Amnon had a friend whose name was Jonadab. He was the son of David’s brother Shimeah. And Jonadab was very good at making plans.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said to Amnon, “O son of the king, why are you so sad from day to day? Will you not tell me?” Amnon said to him, “I am in love with Tamar, the sister of my brother Absalom.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jonadab said to him, “Lie down on your bed and pretend to be sick. When your father comes to see you, say to him, ‘I beg you, let my sister Tamar come and give me some food to eat. Let her make food ready here so I can see it and eat it from her hand.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Amnon lay down and pretended to be sick. When the king came to see him, Amnon said to him, “I beg you, let my sister Tamar come and make two loaves beside me, that I may eat from her hand.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David sent home for Tamar, saying, “Go now to your brother Amnon’s house, and make food for him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Tamar went to her brother Amnon’s house. He was lying down. And she took dough and made loaves so he could watch. Then she baked them ready to eat.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And she took the dish and held it out in front of him. But he would not eat. Amnon said, “Have everyone leave me.” So everyone left him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Amnon said to Tamar, “Bring the food to my room, so I may eat from your hand.” So Tamar took the loaves she had made and brought them to her brother Amnon in his room.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When she brought them to him to eat, he took hold of her and said, “Come, lie with me, my sister.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But she said, “No, my brother. Do not make me. For such a thing is not done in Israel. Do not do this bad and foolish thing!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As for me, where could I get rid of my shame? And as for you, you would be like one of the fools in Israel. So now I beg you, speak to the king, for he will not keep me from you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Amnon would not listen to her. Being stronger than she, he made her lay with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Amnon hated her very much. He hated her more than he had loved her. He said to her, “Get up! Go away!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But she said to him, “No! Sending me away is worse than what you have done to me!” But he would not listen to her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He called the young man who helped him and said, “Throw this woman out of my house, and lock the door behind her.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now she was wearing a dress which covered her arms. For this is how the king’s daughters dressed when they had never had a man. The man who helped Amnon took her out and locked the door behind her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Tamar put ashes on her head. She tore the dress she was wearing which covered her arms. And she put her hand on her head and went away with a loud cry.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Absalom her brother said to her, “Has your brother Amnon been with you? Be quiet now, my sister. He is your brother. Do not take this to heart.” So Tamar stayed in her brother Absalom’s house, sad and alone.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When King David heard about all this, he was very angry.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Absalom did not speak good or bad to Amnon. Absalom hated Amnon because he had put his sister to shame.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After two full years, Absalom had men cut the wool from the sheep in Baal-hazor, near Ephraim. And Absalom asked all the king’s sons to come.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He came to the king and said, “See, your servant has men to cut the wool from the sheep. Let the king and his men go with your servant.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the king said to Absalom, “No, my son. We should not all go, or we will be trouble for you.” Absalom tried to talk him into going. The king prayed that good would come to him, but he would not go with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Absalom said, “If you will not go, let my brother Amnon go with us.” And the king said to him, “Why should he go with you?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when Absalom kept asking him, he let Amnon and all the king’s sons go with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Absalom told his servants, “Watch when Amnon’s heart is happy with wine. When I say to you, ‘Kill Amnon,’ then put him to death. Do not be afraid. Have not I myself told you to do it? Have strength of heart.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Absalom’s servants did to Amnon just as Absalom had told them. Then all the king’s sons got up on their horses and left in a hurry.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While they were on their way, the news came to David, saying, “Absalom has killed all the king’s sons. Not one of them is left.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king got up and tore his clothes, and lay on the ground. And all his servants standing beside him tore their clothes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Jonadab, the son of David’s brother Shimeah, said, “Do not let my lord think they have killed all the young men, the king’s sons. Only Amnon is dead. Absalom has wanted to kill him since the day he put his sister Tamar to shame.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So do not let my lord the king take this to heart and think that all the king’s sons are dead, for only Amnon is dead.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Absalom had run away. And the young man who kept watch looked up and saw many people coming from the road behind him by the side of the mountain.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jonadab said to the king, “See, the king’s sons have come. What your servant said is true.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As soon as he had finished speaking, the king’s sons came and cried in a loud voice. The king and all his servants cried also.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Absalom ran away and went to Talmai the son of Ammihud, the king of Geshur. And David was filled with sorrow for his son every day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Absalom had run away to Geshur, and was there three years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The spirit of King David wanted very much to go out to Absalom. For he was comforted about Amnon, since he was dead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Joab the son of Zeruiah saw that the king missed Absalom very much.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Joab sent for a wise woman from Tekoa, and said to her, “Pretend to be filled with sorrow. Dress as if you were filled with sorrow, and do not pour oil on yourself. Dress like a woman who has been filled with sorrow for the dead many days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then go to the king and speak to him in this way.” And Joab told her what to say.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the woman of Tekoa spoke to the king, she fell on her face to the ground, showing honor, and said, “Help, O king.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king said to her, “What is your trouble?” And she answered, “I am a woman whose husband has died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Your woman servant had two sons. But they fought together in the field and there was no one to pull them apart. So one hit the other and killed him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now the whole family has come against your woman servant. They say, ‘Give us the one who killed his brother. We must put him to death for the life of his brother whom he killed.’ So I would be without a son to receive what belonged to his parents when I die. They would put out the last of the fire which is left to me. My husband would be left without a name and with no children on the earth.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king said to the woman, “Go to your house. I will say what should be done about your trouble.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The woman of Tekoa said to the king, “O my lord the king, the sin is on me and my father’s family. But the king and his throne are without guilt.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king said, “If anyone says anything to you, bring him to me. And he will not touch you again.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then she said, “I beg the king to remember the Lord your God, that the one who punishes for blood will stop destroying. Or my son might be destroyed.” And the king said, “As the Lord lives, not one hair of your son will fall to the ground.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the woman said, “Let your woman servant speak to my lord the king.” And he said, “Speak.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The woman said, “Why then have you planned such a thing against the people of God? For in deciding in this way, the king is as one who is guilty. For the king does not bring home his son who has been driven away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It is sure that we will die. We are like water poured on the ground, which cannot be picked up again. But God does not take away life. He plans ways so that the one who is driven away may not be kept away from Him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I have come to say this to my lord the king because the people have made me afraid. Your woman servant thought, ‘I will speak to the king. It might be that the king will do what his woman servant asks.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For the king will hear and save his woman servant from the man who would destroy both me and my son from the gift of God.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then your woman servant thought, ‘The word of my lord the king will comfort me. For my lord the king is like the angel of God in understanding what is good and bad. May the Lord your God be with you.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king said to the woman, “Do not hide anything from me that I ask you.” And the woman said, “Let my lord the king speak.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the king said, “Is Joab with you in all this?” The woman answered, “As your soul lives, my lord the king, no one can turn to the right or left from anything my lord the king has said. Yes, it was your servant Joab who told me to do this. It was he who put all these words in the mouth of your woman servant.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Your servant Joab has done this to change the way things are now. But my lord is wise like the angel of God, to know all that is on the earth.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king said to Joab, “See now, I will do this. Go and bring back the young man Absalom.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Joab fell on his face to the ground in honor and thanks to the king. Joab said, “Today your servant knows that I have found favor in your eyes, O my lord the king. Because the king has done what his servant has asked of him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Joab got up and went to Geshur, and brought Absalom to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the king said, “Let him go to his own house. Do not let him see my face.” So Absalom went to his own house and did not see the king’s face.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now there was no one in Israel as good looking and as much praised as Absalom. There was nothing wrong with him from the bottom of his foot to the top of his head.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At the end of every year he would cut the hair from his head, for it was heavy on him. When he cut it, he weighed the hair of his head. It weighed as much as 200 pieces of silver, by the king’s weight.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Three sons were born to Absalom, and one daughter whose name was Tamar. She was a beautiful woman.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Absalom lived two whole years in Jerusalem, and did not see the king’s face.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Absalom sent for Joab, to send him to the king. But Joab would not come to him. So he sent for him a second time. But he would not come.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said to his servants, “See, Joab’s field is next to mine, and he has barley there. Go and set it on fire.” So Absalom’s servants burned the field.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joab got up and came to Absalom at his house, and said to him, “Why have your servants burned my field?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Absalom answered Joab, “I sent for you, saying, ‘Come here, that I may send you to say to the king, “Why have I come from Geshur? It would have been better for me to stay there.”’ Now let me see the king’s face. If there is guilt in me, let him put me to death.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joab went to the king and told him. And he called for Absalom. So he came to the king and put his face to the ground in front of him. And the king kissed Absalom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After this, Absalom got a war-wagon and horses, and fifty men to run in front of him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He used to get up early and stand beside the way to the gate. When any man had a problem to be decided upon by the king, Absalom would call to him and say, “What city are you from?” And he would answer, “Your servant is from one of the families of Israel.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Absalom would say to him, “Your side of the problem is good and right. But there is no man to listen to you for the king.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Absalom would say, “If only I were chosen to be the one to be judge in the land! Then every man who has a problem could come to me. And I would do for him what is right and fair.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When a man came near to put his face to the ground in front of him, Absalom would put out his hand and take hold of him and kiss him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He acted this way toward all those of Israel who came with a problem for the king to judge. So Absalom became friends with the men of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At the end of four years, Absalom said to the king, “I ask you, let me go to Hebron and keep my promise that I have promised to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For your servant made a promise while I was living at Geshur in Syria, saying, ‘If the Lord will bring me again to Jerusalem, then I will serve the Lord.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the king said to him, “Go in peace.” So he got up and went to Hebron.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Absalom sent men to go in secret through all the families of Israel. He said to them, “As soon as you hear the sound of the horn, then say, ‘Absalom is king at Hebron.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: With Absalom went 200 men from Jerusalem. They had been asked to come, and did not know what Absalom had planned.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While Absalom was giving gifts on the altar in worship, he sent for Ahithophel the Gilonite, from his city Giloh. He was the man who talked with David about what to do. The plans against David became strong. For more and more people joined Absalom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then a man came to David with news, saying, “The hearts of the men of Israel are with Absalom.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David said to all his servants who were with him at Jerusalem, “Get up and let us run. Or else none of us will be safe from Absalom. Hurry and go, or he will be quick to catch us and bring trouble upon us. He would destroy the city with the sword.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king’s servants said to him, “See, your servants are ready to do whatever my lord the king chooses.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the king left with all those of his house. But he left ten of his women to take care of the house.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king left with all the people, and they stopped at the last house.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All his servants passed by him, and all the Cherethites, Pelethites, Gittites, and 600 men who had come with him from Gath. They all passed by the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king said to Ittai the Gittite, “Why do you go with us also? Return and stay with the king. For you are from another land and have been driven from your home.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You came only yesterday. Should I make you go with us today, when I do not know where I am going? Return with your brothers. May loving-kindness and faith be with you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Ittai said to the king, “As the Lord lives, and as my lord the king lives, your servant will be where my lord the king may be, in death or in life.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David said to him, “Go then, pass on.” And Ittai the Gittite passed on, with all his men and all the little ones who were with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the country was crying with a loud voice as all the people passed by. The king crossed the river Kidron, and all the people went on toward the desert.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Zadok came also, with all the Levites who carried the special box with the Law of God. Abiathar had the special box of God put down until all the people had passed out of the city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king said to Zadok, “Return the special box of God to the city. If I find favor in the eyes of the Lord, He will have me return. And He will have me see both it and His family.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if He says, ‘I have no joy in you,’ then here I am. Let Him do to me what He thinks is good.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the king said to Zadok the religious leader, “Are you not a man who speaks for God? Return to the city in peace with Abiathar and your two sons, your son Ahimaaz and Abiathar’s son Jonathan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: See, I will wait in the desert by the place where the river is crossed, until I hear from you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Zadok and Abiathar returned the special box of God to Jerusalem and stayed there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David went up the Mount of Olives and cried as he went. His head was covered and he wore no shoes. And all the people who were with him covered their heads and went up crying as they went.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now David was told, “Ahithophel is among those who are making plans with Absalom.” And David said, “O Lord, I pray, make the words of Ahithophel foolish.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As David was coming to the top of the mountain, where God was worshiped, Hushai the Archite met him. His coat was torn and there was dust on his head.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David said to him, “If you go with me, you will be trouble for me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if you return to the city, you can bring trouble to the words of Ahithophel for me. Say to Absalom, ‘I will be your servant, O king. I will work for you as I have worked for your father in the past.’ Then you can make the words of Ahithophel foolish for me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Will not Zadok and Abiathar the religious leaders be there with you? Tell Zadok and Abiathar whatever you hear from the king’s house.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Their two sons are with them there, Zadok’s son Ahimaaz and Abiathar’s son Jonathan. By them you can send me news of all that you hear.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David’s friend Hushai came into Jerusalem, just as Absalom was coming into the city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David had gone a short way past the mountain top, Mephibosheth’s servant Ziba met him with two donkeys ready for traveling. On them were 200 loaves of bread, 100 vines of dried grapes, 100 summer fruits, and a bottle of wine.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king said to Ziba, “Why do you have these?” And Ziba said, “The donkeys are for those of the king’s house to travel on. The bread and summer fruit are for the young men to eat. And the wine drink is for whoever is weak in the desert.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king said, “Where is your owner’s son?” And Ziba answered, “He is staying in Jerusalem. For he said, ‘Today the family of Israel will return to me the nation of my father.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the king said to Ziba, “See, all that belongs to Mephibosheth is yours.” And Ziba said, “I bow down in honor to you. O my lord the king, let me find favor in your eyes!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When King David came to Bahurim, there came out a man of the family of Saul. His name was Shimei, the son of Gera. He did not stop speaking bad things as he came.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He threw stones at David, and at all the servants of King David. And all the people and all the strong men were at his right and at his left.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Shimei said as he said bad things, “Get out! Get out, you man of blood, you man of no worth!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord has punished you for all the blood of the family of Saul, in whose place you have ruled! The Lord has given the nation to your son Absalom! Your trouble is upon you, because you are a man of blood!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Zeruiah’s son Abishai said to the king, “Why should this dead dog speak against my lord the king? Let me go now and cut off his head.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the king said, “What have I to do with you, O sons of Zeruiah? If he speaks against me, and if the Lord has told him, ‘Speak against David,’ then who should say, ‘Why have you done so?’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David said to Abishai and all his servants, “See, my own son wants to kill me. How much more now may this Benjamite? Let him alone and let him speak against me, for the Lord has told him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It may be that the Lord will look upon my trouble and return good to me instead of his bad words today.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David and his men went on the way. And Shimei went beside him on the hill. He spoke against David as he went, and threw stones and dust at him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king and all the people with him were tired when they came to the Jordan. There he rested and received new strength.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Absalom and all the people, the men of Israel, came into Jerusalem. And Ahithophel was with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David’s friend Hushai the Archite came to Absalom, Hushai said to him, “Long live the king! Long live the king!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Absalom said to Hushai, “Is this your kindness to your friend? Why did you not go with your friend?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hushai said to Absalom, “No! I will belong to whoever is chosen by the Lord, this people, and all the men of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And whom should I serve? Should I not serve his son? As I have served your father, so I will serve you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Absalom said to Ahithophel, “Give your wise words. What should we do?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahithophel answered, “Go in to your father’s women, whom he has left to take care of the house. Then all Israel will hear that you have made yourself hated by your father. Then the hands of all who are with you will be made stronger.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they set up a tent for Absalom on the roof. And Absalom went in to his father’s women so that the eyes of all Israel could see.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The words that Ahithophel spoke in those days were as if one had asked for the Word of God. Both David and Absalom thought of Ahithophel’s words in this way.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Ahithophel said to Absalom, “Let me choose 12,000 men, and I will leave and go after David tonight.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will come upon him while he is tired and weak. I will fill him with fear so that all the people who are with him will run away. Then I will kill the king alone
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and return all the people to you. All will return if the man you want to kill is dead. Then all the people will be at peace.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The plan pleased Absalom and all the leaders of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Absalom said, “Call Hushai the Archite also. Let us hear what he has to say.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Hushai had come to Absalom, Absalom said to him, “Ahithophel has said this. Should we do as he says? If not, tell us.”
verses.speaker: Narrator
