verses.text: So Hushai said to Absalom, “This time what Ahithophel has said to do is not good.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hushai said, “You know your father and his men. They are powerful and angry, like a bear robbed of her young ones in the field. And your father is a very able man of war. He will not stay with the people during the night.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He has now hidden himself in one of the caves, or in another place. When some of the people are killed in the first battle, whoever hears it will say, ‘There have been many people killed who follow Absalom.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Even the one who has strength of heart like the heart of a lion will be afraid. For all Israel knows that your father is a powerful man, and that those who are with him are men with strength of heart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But I say that all Israel should be gathered to you, from Dan to Beersheba, as much as the sand by the sea. And you yourself should go into battle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So we will find David wherever he is. We will fall on him like water falls on the ground in the early morning. And not he or any of the men with him will be left.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If he runs into a city, then all Israel will bring ropes to that city. We will pull it into the valley until not even a small stone is left there.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Absalom and all the men of Israel said, “The words of Hushai the Archite are better than the words of Ahithophel.” In this way the Lord had planned to destroy the good leading of Ahithophel, so He might bring trouble to Absalom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hushai said to Zadok and Abiathar the religious leaders, “This is what Ahithophel said that Absalom and the leaders of Israel should do. And this is what I have said they should do.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So be quick to send someone to tell David, ‘Do not stay the night in the desert beside the place where the Jordan is crossed. But cross over, or the king and all the people with him will be destroyed.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Jonathan and Ahimaaz were staying at Enrogel. And a woman servant would go and tell them, and they would go and tell King David. For they could not be seen coming into the city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But a boy saw them, and told Absalom. So the two of them left in a hurry and came to the house of a man in Bahurim. He had a well in the open space in the center of his house. And they went down into it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the woman took the covering and spread it over the well’s mouth, and spread grain on it, so nothing was known of it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Absalom’s servants came to the woman at the house and said, “Where are Ahimaaz and Jonathan?” The woman answered, “They have crossed the river.” And after looking and not finding them, they returned to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they had left, Ahimaaz and Jonathan came up out of the well and went and told King David. They said to David, “Be quick to get ready and cross over the water. For Ahithophel has told them to come against you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David and all the people with him got up and crossed the Jordan. By the light of morning, not one was left who had not crossed the Jordan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Ahithophel saw that his words were not followed, he got onto his donkey and went home to his city. He told those of his family what they must do, and he hanged himself. So he died and was buried in his father’s grave.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David came to Mahanaim. Absalom and all the men of Israel with him crossed the Jordan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Absalom made Amasa captain of the army instead of Joab. Amasa was the son of a man whose name was Jithra the Israelite, who went in to Nahash’s daughter Abigal, the sister of Joab’s mother Zeruiah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Israel and Absalom set up their tents in the land of Gilead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David had come to Mahanaim, he met Nahash’s son Shobi from Rabbah of the sons of Ammon, Ammiel’s son Machir from Lo-debar, and Barzillai the Gileadite from Rogelim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They brought him beds, washing pots, dishes, grain, flour, seeds,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: honey, sour milk, sheep, and cheese from the cattle, for David and his men to eat. For they said, “The people are hungry and tired and thirsty in the desert.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David numbered the people who were with him. He set over them leaders of thousands and of hundreds.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And he sent the people out. One third of them was under the rule of Joab. One third was under the rule of Zeruiah’s son Abishai, Joab’s brother. And one third was under the rule of Ittai the Gittite. The king said to the people, “I myself will go out with you also.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the people said, “You should not go out. For if we run, they will not care about us. If half of us die, they will not care about us. But you are worth 10,000 of us. So it is better that you send us help from the city.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king said to them, “I will do whatever you think is best.” So the king stood beside the gate, and all the people went out by hundreds and thousands.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king told Joab and Abishai and Ittai, “Be gentle toward the young man Absalom because of me.” And all the people heard him say this to all the leaders about Absalom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the people went out into the field to fight against Israel. The battle was fought among the trees of Ephraim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people of Israel lost the fight there to the servants of David. Twenty thousand men were killed there that day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The battle was spread over the whole country. Dangers from the trees destroyed more people that day than the sword.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Absalom met the servants of David. He was going on his horse, and the horse went under the many branches of a large oak tree. Absalom’s hair caught in the branches of the oak. He was left hanging between heaven and earth, while the horse under him kept going.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When a certain man saw it, he told Joab, “I saw Absalom hanging in an oak.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab said to the man, “You saw him! Why did you not kill him and let him fall to the ground? I would have given you ten pieces of silver and a belt.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The man said to Joab, “Even for a thousand pieces of silver in my hand, I would not go against the king’s son. For we heard the king tell you and Abishai and Ittai, ‘Keep the young man Absalom safe for me.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If I had gone against his life, there is nothing hidden from the king. And you would not have helped me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joab said, “I will not waste time here with you.” He took three spears in his hand and threw them through Absalom’s heart while he was still alive in the oak.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And ten young men who carried Joab’s battle clothes gathered around and hit Absalom and killed him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joab sounded the horn, and all the people returned from going after Israel, for Joab stopped them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They took Absalom and threw him into a deep hole among the trees, and set many stones over him. And all Israel ran away, every one to his own home.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While Absalom was alive, he had set up stones in his honor in the King’s Valley. For he said, “I have no son to let my name be remembered.” So he called the stones after his own name. And they are there to have Absalom be remembered to this day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Zadok’s son Ahimaaz said, “Let me run and bring the king news that the Lord has saved him from those who hate him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Joab said to him, “You must not carry news today, but another time. Today you should carry no news, because the king’s son is dead.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joab said to the Cushite, “Go and tell the king what you have seen.” So the Cushite bowed to Joab and ran.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Zadok’s son Ahimaaz said to Joab, “Whatever happens, let me run after the Cushite.” Joab said, “Why would you run, my son? You would receive no reward for going.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Ahimaaz said, “Whatever happens, I will run.” So Joab said to him, “Run.” Then Ahimaaz ran by way of the plain and passed the Cushite.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David was sitting between the two gates. The man who kept watch went up to the roof of the gate by the wall. He looked up and saw a man running by himself.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The man who kept watch called and told the king. The king said, “If he is by himself, he has good news.” And he came nearer and nearer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the man who kept watch saw another man running. He called to the gate-keeper and said, “See, another man is running by himself.” The king said, “This one is bringing good news also.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the man who kept watch said, “I think the man in front runs like Ahimaaz the son of Zadok.” The king said, “He is a good man, and comes with good news.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahimaaz called and said to the king, “All is well.” He put his face to the ground in front of the king, and said, “Thanks be to the Lord your God. He has given up the men who raised their hands against my lord the king.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king said, “Is it well with the young man Absalom?” And Ahimaaz answered, “When Joab sent the king’s servant, your servant, I heard noise and saw much fighting. But I did not know what it was.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king said, “Turn aside and stand here.” So he turned aside and stood still.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Cushite came and said, “Let my lord the king receive good news. For the Lord has saved you today from all those who came against you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king said to the Cushite, “Is it well with the young man Absalom?” And the Cushite answered, “May those who hate my lord the king, all those who come to do bad things against you, be as that young man!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king filled with much sorrow. He went up to the room above the gate and cried. As he walked he said, “O my son Absalom, my son, my son Absalom! If only I had died instead of you, O Absalom, my son, my son!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joab was told, “See, the king is crying. He is filled with sorrow for Absalom.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the happiness of winning the battle that day was changed to sorrow for all the people. For they heard that day, “The king is filled with sorrow for his son.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the people were quiet as they went in secret into the city that day. They acted like people who are ashamed when they run away from a battle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king covered his face and cried out with a loud voice, “O my son Absalom, O Absalom, my son, my son!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joab came into the house to the king and said, “Today you have covered the faces of all your servants with shame. Today they have saved your life and the lives of your sons and daughters, your wives and the women who act as your wives.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But you love those who hate you, and hate those who love you. You have shown today that rulers and servants are nothing to you. For today I see that if Absalom were alive and all of us were dead, you would be pleased.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So now get up and go out and speak in kindness to your servants. I swear by the Lord that if you do not, for sure not a man will stay with you this night. And this will be worse for you than all the bad things that have happened to you since you were young.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So the king got up and sat in the gate. When they told all the people, “See, the king is sitting in the gate,” then all the people came to the king.
Now every man of Israel had run to his tent.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And all the people in all the family groups of Israel were arguing. They said, “The king saved us from those who hate us. He saved us from the Philistines. But now he has run from Absalom and away from the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We chose Absalom to rule over us and he has died in battle. So now why do you say nothing about bringing the king back?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then King David sent word to Zadok and Abiathar the religious leaders, saying, “Speak to the leaders of Judah. Say to them, ‘Why are you the last to bring the king back to his house? I have heard from all Israel for me to return to my house.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You are my brothers. You are my bone and my flesh. Why should you be the last to bring back the king?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And say to Amasa, ‘Are you not my bone and my flesh? May God do so to me, and more also, if you will not be the captain of my army at all times instead of Joab.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He changed the hearts of all the men of Judah as if they were one man. So they sent word to the king, saying, “Return, you and all your servants.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the king returned and came as far as the Jordan. Judah came to Gilgal to meet the king and bring him over the Jordan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Gera’s son Shimei, the Benjamite from Bahurim, came down in a hurry with the men of Judah to meet King David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There were 1,000 men of Benjamin with him. And Ziba the servant of the family of Saul came with his fifteen sons and twenty servants. They rushed to the king at the Jordan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They crossed the river to bring over those of the king’s house, and to do what pleased him. Gera’s son Shimei fell down in front of the king as he was about to cross the Jordan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said to the king, “Let not my lord think I am guilty. Do not remember what your servant did wrong on the day when my lord the king left Jerusalem. Let not the king take it to heart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For your servant knows that I have sinned. So I have come today. I am the first of all the family of Joseph to come down to meet my lord the king.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Zeruiah’s son Abishai answered, “Should not Shimei be put to death for this? He spoke against the Lord’s chosen one.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But David said, “What have I to do with you, O sons of Zeruiah? Why should you be against me this day? Should any man be put to death in Israel today? For do I not know that this day I am king of Israel?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king said to Shimei, “You will not die.” And the king gave him his promise.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Saul’s grandson Mephibosheth came down to meet the king. He had not dressed his feet, trimmed the hair of his face, or washed his clothes, from the day the king left until the day he returned in peace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he came from Jerusalem to meet the king, David said to him, “Why did you not go with me, Mephibosheth?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He answered, “O my lord the king, my servant lied to me. Your servant had said to him, ‘Get a donkey ready for me to travel on, so I may go with the king.’ Because your servant cannot walk.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And he has spoken against me to my lord the king. But my lord the king is like the angel of God. So do what you think is best.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For all those of my father’s house were nothing but dead men in front of my lord the king. But you set your servant among those who ate at your own table. What right do I have to complain any more to the king?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king said to him, “Why speak any more of how things are with you? I have decided that you and Ziba should divide the land.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Mephibosheth said to the king, “Let him take it all, since my lord the king has come home and is safe.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Barzillai of Gilead had come down from Rogelim. He went on to the Jordan with the king, to lead him over the river.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Barzillai was eighty years old. He had given food to the king while he stayed at Mahanaim, for he was a very rich man.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king said to Barzillai, “You cross over with me, and I will take care of you with me in Jerusalem.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Barzillai said to the king, “How much longer have I to live, that I should go up with the king to Jerusalem?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I am now eighty years old. Can I know the difference between good and bad? Can your servant taste what I eat or what I drink? Can I hear the voice of singing men and women any more? Why should your servant be an added problem to my lord the king?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Your servant will only cross over the Jordan with the king. Why should the king reward me in this good way?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Let your servant return, that I may die in my own city near the grave of my father and mother. But here is your servant Chimham. Let him cross over with my lord the king. And do for him what is good in your eyes.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king answered, “Chimham will cross over with me. And I will do for him what is pleasing to you. I will do for you whatever you ask.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the people crossed over the Jordan, and the king also. Then the king kissed Barzillai and prayed that good would come to him. And Barzillai returned to his own home.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king went on to Gilgal, and Chimham went with him. And all the people of Judah and half the people of Israel went with the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then all the men of Israel came to the king and said to him, “Why have our brothers the men of Judah stolen you away? Why have they brought the king and those of his family over the Jordan, and all David’s men with him?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the men of Judah answered the men of Israel, “Because the king is a close brother to us. Why are you angry about this? Has the king paid for our food? Has he given us any gift?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the men of Israel said to the men of Judah, “We have ten shares in the king. So we have more right to David than you. Why then did you hate us? Were we not the first to speak of bringing back our king?” But the words of the men of Judah had more anger than the words of the men of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A man of no worth happened to be there whose name was Sheba, the son of Bichri, a Benjamite. He sounded the horn and said, “We have no share in David! We have no share in the son of Jesse! Every man to his tents, O Israel!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So all the men of Israel stopped following David, and followed Sheba the son of Bichri. But the men of Judah were not moved from following their king, from the Jordan to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David came to his house at Jerusalem. The king took his ten women whom he had left to take care of the house, and had a prison soldier watch them. David gave them food, but did not go in to them. So they were shut up until the day of their death, living as women whose husbands had died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king said to Amasa, “Call the men of Judah to come to me within three days, and you be here yourself.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Amasa went to call out the men of Judah. But he took longer than the time which had been given him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David said to Abishai, “Now Bichri’s son Sheba will bring us more trouble than Absalom. Take your lord’s servants and go after him. Or he might find strong cities for himself, and get away from us.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Joab’s men went out after him. With them went the Cherethites, the Pelethites and all the strong men. They left Jerusalem to go after Sheba the son of Bichri.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Amasa came to meet them at the large stone in Gibeon. Now Joab was dressed in soldier’s clothing. Over his clothing was a belt with a sword in its holder tied at his side. As he walked, the sword fell out.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab said to Amasa, “Is it well with you, my brother?” And he took Amasa by the hair of his face with his right hand to kiss him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But Amasa did not see the sword which was in Joab’s hand. So Joab hit him in the stomach with it, and poured his inside parts out on the ground. He did not hit him again, and Amasa died.
Then Joab and his brother Abishai went after Sheba the son of Bichri.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now one of Joab’s young men stood by him and said, “Whoever favors Joab and whoever is for David, let him follow Joab.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Amasa lay in his blood in the center of the road. When the man saw that all the people stood still, he took Amasa out of the road and into the field. And he threw a covering over him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After he was taken out of the road, all the men went on and followed Joab to go after Sheba the son of Bichri.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Sheba passed through all the families of Israel to Abel Bethmaacah. Then all the Berites gathered together and followed him into the city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And all the men who were with Joab came and gathered their armies around him in Abel Bethmaacah. They built up a hill of dirt against the wall of the city. And they were trying their best to make the wall fall down.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then a wise woman called from the city, “Listen! I beg you, tell Joab to come here that I may speak with him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So he came to her, and the woman said, “Are you Joab?” He answered, “I am.” Then she said to him, “Listen to the words of your woman servant.” And he answered, “I am listening.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then she said, “In the past they used to say, ‘Let them ask for words of wisdom at Abel.’ And so they would stop fighting.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I am one of peace and faith in Israel. You want to destroy a city and a mother in Israel. Why would you swallow up the gift of the Lord?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab answered, “Far be it from me! Far be it that I should swallow up or destroy!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That is not true. But a man from the hill country of Ephraim has turned against King David. His name is Sheba the son of Bichri. Give up only him, and I will leave the city.” And the woman said to Joab, “See, his head will be thrown to you over the wall.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the woman went to all the people with her plan. And they cut off the head of Sheba the son of Bichri and threw it to Joab. So he sounded the horn and they left the city, every man going to his home. Joab returned to the king at Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Joab was the captain of the whole army of Israel. Benaiah the son of Jehoiada was captain of the Cherethites and the Pelethites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Adoram was captain of those who were made to work. Jehoshaphat the son of Ahilud wrote down the things that happened.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Sheva was the teacher. Zadok and Abiathar were religious leaders.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Ira the Jairite was a religious leader to David also.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While David was king there was a time without food for three years. David went to the Lord. The Lord said, “It is because of Saul and his house of blood, for he put the Gibeonites to death.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the king called the Gibeonites. (Now the Gibeonites were not of the sons of Israel, but of the people who were left of the Amorites. The sons of Israel had made an agreement with them. But Saul had wanted to kill them because he thought so much of the sons of Israel and Judah.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David said to the Gibeonites, “What should I do for you? How can I pay for the sin, so you may bring good to the land of the Lord?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Gibeonites said to him, “We will take no silver or gold from Saul or his family. And it is not for us to put any man to death in Israel.” David said, “I will do for you whatever you say.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they said to the king, “Saul destroyed us and planned to keep us from staying in any land of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Let seven men from his sons be given to us. We will hang them before the Lord at Gibeon on the Lord’s mountain.” And the king said, “I will give them.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the king kept alive Mephibosheth, the son of Saul’s son Jonathan, because David had made a promise to Saul’s son Jonathan before the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king took the two sons of Aiah’s daughter Rizpah, Armoni and Mephibosheth, whom she had born to Saul. And he took the five sons of Saul’s daughter Merab, whom she had born to Adriel the son of Barzillai the Meholathite.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He gave them to the Gibeonites, and they hanged them on the mountain before the Lord. The seven of them died together. They were put to death in the first days of gathering time, when the barley was ready to gather.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Aiah’s daughter Rizpah spread cloth made from hair on the rock for herself to lie upon, from the beginning of gathering time until the rain fell from the sky upon the bodies. She would not let the birds of the sky rest on them during the day, or the animals of the field during the night.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David was told what Aiah’s daughter Rizpah, Saul’s woman, had done.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he went and took the bones of Saul and his son Jonathan from the men of Jabesh-gilead. They had stolen them from the open space in the center of Bethshan. That was where the Philistines had hanged them on the day they killed Saul in Gilboa.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David brought the bones of Saul and his son Jonathan. They gathered the bones of those who had been hanged.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And they buried the bones of Saul and his son Jonathan in the country of Benjamin in Zela, in the grave of Kish his father. They did all that the king told them to do. After that, God heard and answered when they prayed for the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Philistines were at war again with Israel. David went down with his servants and they fought the Philistines. And David became tired.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Ishbi-benob wanted to kill David. He was one of the sons of the very tall and strong people. His spear weighed as much as 300 pieces of brass, and he had a new sword.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Zeruiah’s son Abishai helped David and killed the Philistine. Then David’s men promised him, “You will not go out again with us to battle. You might put out the lamp of Israel.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After this there was war again with the Philistines at Gob. Then Sibbecai the Hushathite killed Saph, who was one of the sons of the very tall and strong people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was war with the Philistines again at Gob. And Elhanan the son of Jaare-oregim the Bethlehemite killed Goliath the Gittite. Goliath’s spear was like the heavy piece of wood used by a cloth-maker.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was war at Gath again. There was a very tall man there who had six fingers on each hand and six toes on each foot, twenty-four in number. He was one of the sons of the very tall and strong people also.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he spoke against Israel, Jonathan the son of Shimei, David’s brother, killed him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These four were sons of the very tall and strong people in Gath. They were killed by David and his servants.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David spoke the words of this song to the Lord on the day the Lord saved him from all who hated him, and from Saul.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said, “The Lord is my rock, my strong place, and the One Who sets me free.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He is my God, my rock, where I go to be safe. He is my covering and the horn that saves me, my strong place where I go to be safe. You save me from being hurt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I call upon the Lord, Who should be praised. I am saved from those who hate me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “For the waves of death were all around me. The storm that destroys made me afraid.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The cords of the grave were around me. The nets of death came against me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In my trouble I called upon the Lord. Yes, I cried to my God. From His house He heard my voice. My cry for help came into His ears.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Then the earth shook. The mountains were shaking. They shook because He was angry.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Smoke went up from His nose. Fire that destroyed came from His mouth. Burnt pieces of wood were set on fire by it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He tore open the heavens and came down, with darkness under His feet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He sat on a cherub and flew. He was seen on the wings of the wind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He made darkness around Him his tent, gathering waters, and clouds of the sky.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: From the light before Him, burnt pieces of wood were set on fire.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “The Lord thundered from heaven. The Most High let His voice be heard.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He sent out arrows, and made them run. He sent lightning, and made them troubled and afraid.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the bottom of the sea was seen. The bottom of the world lost its covering, at the strong words of the Lord, at the rush of breath from His nose.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “He sent from above. He took me. He pulled me out of many waters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He saved me from those strong ones who hated me. For they were too strong for me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They came upon me in the day of my trouble. But the Lord held me up.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He brought me into a big place. He saved me, because He was pleased with me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “The Lord has paid me for being right with Him. He has paid me for my clean hands.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For I have kept the ways of the Lord. I have not acted in sin against my God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For all His Laws were in front of me, and I did not turn aside from them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I was without blame before Him. I kept myself from guilt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the Lord has paid me for being right with Him, for being clean in His eyes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “With the faithful You show Yourself faithful. With the one without blame You show Yourself without blame.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: With the pure You show Yourself pure. But with the sinful, You show Yourself wise.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You save a troubled people. But Your eyes are on the proud whom You put to shame.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “For You are my lamp, O Lord. The Lord gives light to my darkness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For by You I can run through an army. By my God I can jump over a wall.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As for God, His way is perfect. The Word of the Lord is proven true. He is a covering to all who go to Him to be safe.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “For who is God, but the Lord? Who is a Rock, except our God?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God is my strong place. He has made my way safe.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He makes my feet like the feet of a deer. He sets me safe on high places.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He makes my hands ready for battle, so that my arms can use a bow of brass.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “You have given me the covering of Your saving power. Your help makes me strong.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You give me a big place for my steps. I have not fallen.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I went after those who hated me and destroyed them. I did not return until they were destroyed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I destroyed them and cut them through, so that they did not rise. They fell under my feet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For You have dressed me with strength for battle. You have put under me those who came against me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You made those who fought me turn their backs to me. I destroyed those who hated me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They looked, but there was no one to save them. They cried to the Lord, but He did not answer them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then I beat them as fine as the dust of the earth. I crushed and stepped on them like the mud of the streets.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “You have saved me from trouble with my people. You have kept me as head of the nations. People whom I have not known serve me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Strangers obey me. As soon as they heard of me, they obeyed me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Strangers lost their strength of heart. They came out of their secret places shaking with fear.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “The Lord lives. Thanks be to my Rock. May God be honored, the Rock that saves me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He is the God Who punishes for me. He puts people under my rule.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He makes me free from those who hate me. You lift me above those who come against me. You save me from the man who wants to hurt me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So I will give thanks to You among the nations, O Lord. I will sing praises to Your name.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: With great power He saves His king. He shows loving-kindness to His chosen one, to David and his children forever.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now these are the last words of David. David the son of Jesse, the man who was raised on high, the chosen one of the God of Jacob, the sweet song writer of Israel, says,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “The Spirit of the Lord spoke by me. His Word was on my tongue.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The God of Israel has spoken. The Rock of Israel said to me, ‘When one is right and good in ruling over men, ruling in the fear of God,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: he shines on them like the morning light. He is like the sunshine on a morning without clouds. He is like rain that makes the new grass grow out of the earth through sunshine after rain.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In truth, does not my house stand right with God? For He has made an agreement with me that lasts forever. It is planned right in all things, and sure. For will He not make all my help and my desire grow?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But those of no worth are all like thorns that are thrown away, because they cannot be taken with the hand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The man who touches them must be covered with iron and have a spear. All of them will be burned up with fire as they sit.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These are the names of David’s men of war. There was Josheb-basshebeth a Tahchemonite, head of the three. He was called Adino the Eznite, because he had killed 800 men at one time.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Next to him among the three strong men was Eleazar the son of Dodo the Ahohite. He was with David when they spoke against the Philistines who were gathered there for battle, and the men of Israel had left.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Eleazar got up and killed the Philistines until his hand was tired from holding the sword. The Lord saved many of His people that day. The men returned after him only to take what had belonged to the dead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Next to him was Shammah the son of Agee a Hararite. The Philistines were gathered together at Lehi, where there was a piece of ground full of lentil plants. The people ran from the Philistines.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Shammah stood in the center of the piece of ground and fought for it. He killed the Philistines. The Lord saved many of His people that day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then three of the thirty leaders went down to David during the gathering time to the cave of Adullam. The Philistine army was staying in the valley of Rephaim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David was in the strong place, while the Philistine soldiers were in Bethlehem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David had a desire and said, “If only someone would give me water to drink from the well by the gate of Bethlehem!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the three strong men broke through the Philistine army and took water from the well by the gate of Bethlehem. They brought it to David. But David would not drink it. He poured it out to the Lord,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and said, “O Lord, far be it from me to do this. Should I drink the blood of the men who went and put their lives in danger?” So he would not drink it. The three strong men did these things.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Abishai the brother of Joab, son of Zeruiah, was head of the thirty. He fought with his spear against 300 men and killed them. His name was respected as well as the three.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He was the most honored of the thirty. So he became their captain. But he was not as strong as the three.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Benaiah the son of Jehoiada was a man of Kabzeel with strength of heart. He had done powerful things. He killed the two sons of Ariel of Moab. And he went down and killed a lion in a hole while the snow was falling.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He killed an Egyptian, an important man. The Egyptian had a spear in his hand. But Benaiah went down to him with a heavy stick and took the spear from the Egyptian’s hand. Then he killed him with his own spear.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Benaiah the son of Jehoiada did these things. His name was respected as well as the three strong men.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He was honored among the thirty. But he was not as strong as the three. David made him captain of the soldiers who kept him from danger.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab’s brother Asahel was among the thirty. Then there was Elhanan the son of Dodo of Bethlehem,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Shammah the Harodite, Elika the Harodite,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Helez the Paltite, Ira the son of Ikkesh the Tekoite,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abiezer the Anathothite, and Mebunnai the Hushathite.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was Zalmon the Ahohite, Maharai the Netophathite,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Heleb the son of Baanah the Netophathite, and Ittai the son of Ribai of Gibeah of the sons of Benjamin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was Benaiah a Pirathonite, Hiddai of the rivers of Gaash,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abialbon the Arbathite, Azmaveth the Barhumite,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Eliahba the Shaalbonite, the sons of Jashen, and Jonathan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was Shammah the Hararite, Ahiam the son of Sharar the Ararite,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Eliphelet the son of Ahasbai of Maacah, Eliam the son of Ahithophel of Gilo,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hezro the Carmelite, and Paarai the Arbite.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was Igal the son of Nathan of Zobah, Bani the Gadite,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Zelek the Ammonite, Naharai the Beerothite, the one who carried the battle clothes of Joab the son of Zeruiah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And there was Ira the Ithrite, Gareb the Ithrite,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and Uriah the Hittite. There were thirty-seven in all.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Again the anger of the Lord burned against Israel. He moved David against them, saying, “Go, number Israel and Judah.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the king said to Joab the captain of the army who was with him, “Go through all the families of Israel, from Dan to Beersheba. Number the people, so I may know how many there are.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Joab said to the king, “May the Lord your God add to the people a hundred times as many as they are. And may it be while the eyes of my lord the king still see. But why does my lord the king find this thing pleasing?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the king’s word was stronger than Joab and the captains of the army. So Joab and the army leaders went out from the king to number the people of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They crossed the Jordan and stopped at Aroer, on the south side of the city in the center of the valley of Gad. And they went on to Jazer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they came to Gilead, and to the land of Tahtimhodshi. They came to Dan-jaan and around to Sidon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They came to the strong place of Tyre and to all the cities of the Hivites and the Canaanites. And they went out to the south of Judah, to Beersheba.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they had gone through the whole land, they came to Jerusalem. They had traveled nine months and twenty days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Joab gave the number of the people to the king. There were 800,000 strong men in Israel who used the sword, and 500,000 men of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David’s heart troubled him after he had numbered the people. So he said to the Lord, “I have sinned. But now I beg you, O Lord. Take away the sin of Your servant, for I have acted like a fool.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David got up in the morning, the word of the Lord came to Gad, the one who spoke for God to David. The Lord said,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Go and tell David, ‘This is what the Lord says: “I give you three things to choose from. Choose one of them, that I may do it to you.”’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Gad came to David and told him, and said, “Will you have seven years without food in your land? Or will you run from those who hate you for three months, while they come after you? Or will there be disease in your land for three days? Now think about it. Decide what answer I should return to Him Who sent me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David said to Gad, “I am in much trouble. Let us fall into the hand of the Lord, for His loving-kindness is great. But do not let me fall into the hand of man.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the Lord sent a disease upon Israel from the morning until the time given. And 70,000 men died, from Dan to Beersheba.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The angel put out his hand to destroy Jerusalem. But the Lord had pity on them because of their trouble. He said to the angel who destroyed the people, “It is enough! Do no more!” The angel of the Lord was by the grain-floor of Araunah the Jebusite.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David saw the angel who was killing the people, he said to the Lord, “See, it is I who have sinned. It is I who have done wrong. But these sheep, what have they done? I beg You, let Your hand be against me and my father’s family.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Gad came to David and said, “Go up and build an altar to the Lord on the grain-floor of Araunah the Jebusite.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David went up at Gad’s word, just as the Lord had told him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Araunah looked, and saw the king and his servants crossing over toward him. And he went out and put his face to the ground in front of the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Araunah said, “Why has my lord the king come to his servant?” David answered, “To buy the grain-floor from you, to build an altar to the Lord. Then the disease may be kept away from the people.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Araunah said to David, “Let my lord the king take whatever is good in his eyes, and make a gift of it. Look, there are the bulls for the burnt gift. The tools for cleaning the grain, and the cross-pieces the bulls wear to pull loads, can be used for the wood.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Araunah gives all this to the king.” And Araunah said, “May the Lord your God be pleased with your gift.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the king said to Araunah, “No, I will buy it from you for a price. I will not give burnt gifts to the Lord my God which I do not pay for.” So David bought the grain-floor and the bulls for fifty pieces of silver.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And David built an altar there to the Lord. He gave burnt gifts and peace gifts. So the Lord listened to the prayers for the land, and stopped the disease in Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator
